availability.p: Material from the Romantic Circles Website may not be downloaded, reproduced or disseminated in any manner without authorization unless it is for purposes of criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching, and/or classroom use as provided by the Copyright Act of 1976, as amended.

Unless otherwise noted, all Pages and Resources mounted on Romantic Circles are copyrighted by the author/editor and may be shared only in accordance with the Fair Use provisions of U.S. copyright law. Except as expressly permitted by this statement, redistribution or republication in any medium requires express prior written consent from the author/editors and advance notification of Romantic Circles. Any requests for authorization should be forwarded to Romantic Circles:> Romantic Circlesc/o Professor Neil FraistatDepartment of EnglishUniversity of MarylandCollege Park, MD 20742fraistat@umd.edu

By their use of these texts and images, users agree to the following conditions:
These texts and images may not be used for any commercial purpose without prior written permission from Romantic Circles.
These texts and images may not be re-distributed in any forms other than their current ones.

Users are not permitted to download these texts and images in order to mount them on their own servers. It is not in our interest or that of our users to have uncontrolled subsets of our holdings available elsewhere on the Internet. We make corrections and additions to our edited resources on a continual basis, and we want the most current text to be the only one generally available to all Internet users. Institutions can, of course, make a link to the copies at Romantic Circles, subject to our conditions of use.

quotation.p: All quotation marks and apostrophes have been changed: " for â€œ," for â€, ' for ‘, and ' for '.

hyphenation.p: Any dashes occurring in line breaks have been removed.
Because of web browser variability, all hyphens have been typed on the U.S. keyboard

normalization.p: Writing in other hands appearing on these manuscripts has been indicated as such, the content recorded in brackets.
& has been used for the ampersand sign.
Â£ has been used for Â£, the pound sign
All other characters, those with accents, non-breaking spaces, etc., have been encoded in HTML entity decimals.

list.item: Modifying TEI header and minor markup changes to conform to TEI House style

ab.emph: Note: Given the different conventions of punctuation in manuscripts and in print, variants in punctuation have been excluded.

div.head: Abbreviations
div.p: Mary = Mary, a Series of Reflections During Twenty Years (1811)
CPJ = Collected Poems and Journals of Mary Tighe (2005)

div.head: Volume 1
div.p: 32: Continual hopes deceive, and the vex'd [Verses] = Fallacious hopes the baffled [PWOP]

p.hi: Verses Written at the commencement of Spring. 1802

lg.l: My sickening heart saw hope deferr'd
And sought with thee to cheat the hours,
Thy voice my ear delighted heard
And conquer'd felt vexation's powers
The darkling gloom begins to fly,
The sun shines forth with cheering ray,
The wat'ry mirror of the sky
Brightens in the smiling day.
The vale reviving glows again,
Again th' illumined hills shine clear,
The shadowy clouds flit o'er the plain,
And swiftly shifting, disappear.

p.hi: Verses Written at the Devil's Bridge in Cardigan

div.p: 62: what youth obtains [Verses] = to whom belong [CPJ]
106: kindling breathe celestial [Verses] = kindly breathe a sacred
125-26 omitted in CPJ: "There the soul delights to meet / Kindred soul in converse sweet,"
139-142 reduced from four lines to two:

lg.l: Mild indulgence, white-robed candour,
Warding off the shafts of slander,
To truth's just sentence still referring,
Or thro' partial kindness erring; [Verses]
Charity, benign indulgence,
White rob'd candour, truth's just sentence, [CPJ]

div.p: 162: The ready blush, the [Verses] = Her ready blush, and [CPJ]

p.hi: A faithful friend is the medicine of life

lg.l: Ah! what avail the couch, or curtain'd awning,
The eider's softness, or luxurious bed?
With sleepless, aching eyes I wait thy dawning
While the vain pillow mocks my throbbing head.
Poor fond heart with pleasure swelling
What hast thou to do with joy?
Sorrow still usurps the dwelling
Scatters wide each glitt'ring toy.
From her grotto's brilliant centre
See the Circe pleasure woo,
Oft deluded would I enter
Tho I saw remorse pursue:
Ah! thou bright, thou dangerous charmer!
Flattering trait'ress, gilded snare!
Reason yields me now her armour,
I at length thine arts can dare.
What can sooth this bitter sorrow?
What the soft assuaging balm?
In the sad impending morrow
Who shall bid my soul be calm?

div.p: 42: Taste at last [Verses] = task at length [Selena]

p.hi: IV ["When glowing Phoebus quits the weeping earth"]
VI ["Poor, fond deluded heart! wilt thou again"
VIII ["As one who late hath lost a friend ador'd"]
IX Written in the Church yard at Malvern
XVIII Written at the Eagle's Nest Killarney July 26. 1800
XXI To Cowper and his Mary Aug

div.p: 5: days, and nights [Verses] = nights, and days* [Selena]

div.head: Volume 2

p.hi: Imitation from Jeremiah Chap XXXI. Ver 15. Nov:

lg.l: Despair might then with impious voice
Mock the vain tears of penitence,
And curse existence, not his choice,
Sad boon of free Omnipotence!

p.hi: Address to the West Wind Written at Park Gate Sept:

lg.l: Let them not listen to her fatal song,
Nor trust her pictures, nor believe her tongue,
But gaze astonish'd on the enchanting shore
On forms magnificent ne'er seen before
While pale disease sheds thick unwholesome dews,
And wide their venom tainted gales diffuse
Of poisoned prospects which at distance charm'd
Bright to the eye, with desolation arm'd --
In the dark silence of the grave
Where all things are forgot,
There shall I find the rest I crave,
At length releas'd from thought?
There I at least may cease to feel
The bitterness of life,
The wounds that hope no more can heal,
Her agony of strife.
Oh! welcome then thou dreaded vault!
Thou chilly, cypress gloom!
I hail the shrine which long I sought,
Its only porch, the tomb.
For he had caught the glance of fire,
And seen the mother's sadden'd smile,
And mingled feelings strong inspire
The wish on each to dwell a while.

div.p: 32: soldiers, men like you [Verses] = men of blood like you [PWOP]

lg.l: "And who are these?" the youth exclaim'd,
With pity touch'd, with wonder fill'd,
Er'e yet his cooler reason blam'd
The early hatred deep instill'd.

div.p: 41: But pointing to the [Verses] = "And who are these,-- this [PWOP]
160: encreasing tumult grew [Verses] = increasing tumults grow [PWOP]

lg.l: "Dear Ellen!" faintly he exclaim'd,
"I could not save our Bryan's life"
"Thy brother's love will not be blam'd"
"Unequal, cruel was the strife."
Behind that birch-tree see him stand,"
"Waving its light boughs gracefully:"
"While, threat'ning with his baby hand,"
He chides me that I talk with thee."

p.hi: Written in an Horace given on my birth-day by H. Vaughan. 1804
The Myrtle Written at West Aston. 1808
Sonnet to W. Parnell written at Avondale 1808

div.p: 14 In hers the lovely sister form [Verses] = In thine, the "sister form" [CPJ]
